statement.tex: \\ \textbf{Right or wrong?}\\ (1+x)^{10}\text{ will expand to the following.}

\\ \textbf{Right or wrong?}\\ \text{Your friend says that if the coefficients of }\\ \text{the }(2m+1)^{th}\text{ and }(4m+5)^{th}\text{ terms are equal,}\\ \text{then it can only mean the following.}

reason.tex: \text{The highest power of x in the expansion is }x^{10}.\\ \text{And therefore, only if 'k' changes from }1\to 11\\ \text{would there be a }x^{10}\text{ term (due to }x^{k-1}\text{).}\\ \text{Hence, }(1+x)^n = \sum_{k=1}^{11}\,^{10}C_{k-1}\cdot x^{k-1}.
\text{Look at the expansion in Step 1 again.}\\ \text{Notice that the coefficient for the k-th term}\\ \text{is }^{10}C_{k-1} - \text{ not }^{10}C_k.

m=-2\text{ can't be right. When }m=-2\text{ then }\\ 2m+1=4m+5=-3.\text{ But there cannot }\\ \text{be a }{-3}^{th}\text{ term.} \\ \text{However, there is another option. }\\ \text{Recall that }^nC_k = ^nC_{n-k}.\\ \begin{align} \therefore\,^{10}C_{2m} &= ^{10}C_{4m+4} \\ \implies 2m &= 10 - (4m+4) \implies m = 1 \\ \implies 2m + 1 &= 3\text{ and }4m + 5 = 9. \end{align} \\ \text{Hence, the coefficients of the }3^{rd}\text{ and}\\ 9^{th}\text{ terms are equal.}
